div.head: A DIALOGVE OF DYING WEL.
div.p:

Thow ≈øhalt (my ≈øonne) vnder≈øtaÃÑd, that when I was in the flouri≈øhing age of thirtie yeares, I for≈øook the deceitful world, and retyred my ≈øelf into this ≈øolitarie place, heer to do ≈øome kynde of penance for my former ≈øynnes, and to

Then the MarchaÃÑt ≈øaid to him, it ≈øeemeth too mee a thing very ≈øuperfluous that thow ≈øhoulde≈øt ≈øeek to learne to dy, ≈øeeing thow (beeing a mortal man and alreaddie an hundred yeers old) mu≈øt needs dy, and that verie ≈øhortly. The Eremite an≈øwered, this is that which I feare & not without great a≈øtoni≈øhment do euerie day think vpon, coÃÑ≈øidering that I am not redy for death, and neuerthele≈ø≈øe I know a≈ø≈øuredly that I mu≈øt dy.

To this then quoth the Marchant: what thing is it to know how to dy? The old Ermite an≈øwered him: to know how to dy, is no other thing, then to flie all things that may offend our lord God, and with diligence to doe all that hee commaÃÑdeth, ob≈øeruing obedientlie all his preceptes and commandements, and to be in ≈øuche wi≈øe neat and cleane in coÃÑ≈øcience, that arryuing vnto the la≈øt end of our lyfe wee may be receaued into the euerla≈øting re≈øt of the cittizens

Tel mee I be≈øeech yow, could yow giue mee ≈øome good in≈øtructions touching this mo≈øte nece≈ø≈øarie point of dying wel? HereuÃÑto the Ermite an≈øwered that he was very willing to make him partaker of ≈øuch gaine as alredy him≈øelf had gotten by his ≈øtudy in that ≈øcience, & there-withal a≈øked him what trade hee liued by, hee an≈øwered that hee was a Marchant, whervnto the Ermite added: that the arte of a Marchant is to ≈øel his marchaÃÑ di≈øe deer; and to buy good cheape: yf thow then de≈øire (quoth hee) to make a good market, and to buy a trea≈øure incomparable, and far beyond all e≈øtimation, for a litle price, behold heauen which is ≈øo great and glorious, and buy it with thy temporal goods, giuing them to the poore for thee loue of God.

Then thee MarchaÃÑt beeing de≈øirous
to bee further ≈øatisfied, a≈øked him againe, ≈øaying, o deere father and my good mai≈øter, I pray yow tel mee, yf ≈øo be that you had a ≈øcholler, whome you loued wel, or a ≈øonne, whome you deerely affected, what arte principallie would you teache him? The Ermite an≈øwered: ≈øetting a ≈øyde all ≈øecrets, all artes, all experimentes and all ≈øciences in the world, other arte would I not in≈øtruct him in then in the arte to dy wel, becau≈øe it excelleth euerie other ≈øcience, the≈øame being more nece≈ø≈øarie, more profitable and more worthie, then the others, as without the which a man cannot purcha≈øe paradi≈øe, nor e≈øcape the horrible paynes of hel. The≈øe other artes do teache to di≈øpute, to talke, to mea≈øure, to number, to ≈øing, and ≈øuche like exerci≈øes, which are all of litle value, and only v≈øed of men whyle they liue in this mi≈øerable and tran≈øitorie lyfe, but the arte to dy wel, teacheth thee to get paradi≈øe, where each ≈øcience, and all kynde of knowledge is to bee found: By thee liberal
artes, thow ≈øhalt get wordlie glorie and earthly ≈øub≈øtance, which mo≈øte ≈øpeedely pa≈ø≈øeth a way: but by the arte to dy wel; is gotten the glorie of heauen, which endureth for euer, by this arte is our ≈øoule ≈øaued, and wee haue this life onlie to the end, to learne the arte to dy wel. To this our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øte doth inuite vs, in many places of the go≈øpel: as where hee ≈øaith:Math. 25. E≈øtote parati quia ne≈øcitis diem neque horam, that is to ≈øay; Bee ye in a reddines, becau≈øe ye know not the day nor the hower. Againe:Luc. 12. E≈øtote parati quia qua hora non putatis filius hominis veniet, that is: Be ye prepared becau≈øe the ≈øonne of man wil come what hower ye think not. To come to this knowlege the ≈øaincts and true philo≈øophers haue taken great trauail and paynes, becau≈øe this ≈øcience alone helpeth more then all the other together. In this day and night the holie fathers did exerci≈øe them≈øelues, and now euerie good religious per≈øon and true deuout Chri≈øtian putteth all his ≈øtudie to learne to dy wel: yea hee is
not a true chri≈øtian, neyther can be called a wi≈øeman which doth not procur ≈øome meanes to learne this ≈øo worthie and ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie a ≈øcience, without which, none can dy wel, nor con≈øequently be ≈øaued. For as ≈øainct Bernard ≈øaith, venientem mortem nemo bene excipit, ni≈øi qui ≈øe ad ip≈øam dum viueret, bonis operibus preparauit, that is, No man doth wel receyue death, but hee that while hee liued, did prepare him≈øelf for it, by good woorkes.

The pa≈ø≈øage of death beeing then more perilous then any other thing (for as muche as that therein either is lo≈øt the ≈øoueraigne good, and eternal damnation purcha≈øed, or els the ble≈ø≈øed & perpetual felicitie is thereby wonne, and the euer during payne of hell is thereby auoyded) wee ought with all carefulnes and diligence to prepare our ≈øelues for that pa≈ø≈øage, in which the whole conclu≈øion and end of all our doings con≈øi≈øteth: becau≈øe hauing made this pa≈ø≈øage as it requireth & with behooful meanes, wee become happie for

If a iudge were to giue ≈øenteÃÑce in a ca≈øe whereon depended thy whole ≈øub≈øtaÃÑce, or yf thow weare to yeeld accoÃÑpte of ≈øome admini≈øtratioÃÑ or office of great importance, thow woulde≈øt not fynde repo≈øe either night or day, thow woulde≈øt not ≈øleep one hower ≈øoundlie, nor eate one mor≈øel of meat with plea≈øing ta≈øte, thow woulde≈øt neuer laugh nor v≈øe any recreation vntil ≈øuch tyme as thow wert freed from that perillous e≈øtate and bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. When an impri≈øoned malefactor ‚Ä¢ ath receaued ≈øentence of death and knoweth hee cannot e≈øcape, oh how many waylings, and how many lameÃÑ tings maketh the wretche in that time,

When the marchant had vnder≈øtood all the≈øe things, being then brought into great perplexitie, he ≈øaid vnto the Ermite, o father and mai≈øter I harte ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ de≈øire that you wil vouch≈øafe to in≈øtruct mee further in this ≈øo woorthie and nece≈ø≈øarie arte, of dying wel, that I

div.head: THE DIVISION OF HIS NARATION.
div.p: THe doctrine of dying wel conteyneth three chapters and twelue golden rules.
The fir≈øt fowre, in the fir≈øt chapter, are called rules of health, for that whyles wee are in health they teache the meanes to di≈øpo≈øe our ≈øelues for death.
The other fowre are called in the ≈øecond chapter rules of infirmitie, which wee ought to ob≈øerue for dying wel, in our ≈øicknes.

The fowre la≈øt are called in the third chapter rules of extremytie, becau≈øe wee are by them
in≈øtructed in fowre principal pointes which wee ought to ob≈øerue at the la≈øt end of our lyf, to the end to pa≈ø≈øe ≈øecurely the pa≈ø≈øage of death.

p.hi: The fir≈øt chapter ≈øheweth the long preparation that a man is to make during the tyme of his health.
The ≈øecond chapter ≈øheweth the di≈øpo≈øition more neerer which a man is to make in the tyme of ≈øicknes.
The third conteyneth the la≈øt preparation, which a man is to make euen at the very end of his lyf.

div.head: THE FIRST CHAPTER CONTEYNING RVLES of health, ≈øheweth what a man ought to do about dying wel; the whyle he is in good health.
div.p:
The fir≈øt rule. NO man ought to defer vnto the la≈øt hower, to prepare him≈øelf to dy, but very behooful it is that euery one di≈øpo≈øe him≈øelf during the whole tyme of his lyf; that wel he may pa≈ø≈øe the la≈øt pa≈ø≈øage of death. Therefore
then whyle≈øt thow arte in good health ob≈øerue and keepe the≈øe fower fruitful rules. The fir≈øt whereof is this, bee alwayes myndful of death, becau≈øe therein is conteyned a great ≈øecret which of few is vnder≈øtood, & of fewer practi≈øed, for that by the onlie meditation of death in due manner often v≈øed, ≈øufficient remedie is found again≈øt all our ≈øpiritual infirmities. And therefore Kinges, Princes, Prelates, and riche men of the worlde, who with all indu≈øtrie do put away froÃÑ them the remembraÃÑce of death, do herein greatly offend, becau≈øe more then any other thing they ought to haue it in continuall coÃÑ≈øideration, for that to flie the meditation and remembrance of death is no other thing, then to ca≈øt away from them the grace of the holie gho≈øte, which bringeth oftentimes into the myndes of ≈øinners, ≈øuch feareful remembrance, to the end that being thereby terified, they may more ea≈øelie returne to good lyfe, and attaine to eternal felicitie.

And to the end that this ≈øo good and
profitable doctrine, may alwayes re≈øt fixed in thy mynd, I wil in few wordes declare vnto thee, the marueylous fruites that proceed of this continual memorie of death.

The fir≈øt frute that it produceth is a profound and entyre humilitie:The fir≈øt fruit of the remembraÃÑce of death. for yf thow think often tymes on death, thow doe≈øt aba≈øe and put downe as it were perforce, all pryde arrogancie and in≈øolencie, & become gentle humble and meek. Euen ≈øo a man made proud either through
his riches, beautie of his bodie, or by glorying in his parentage, or for other worldly cau≈øes exalted, yf hee ≈øhal con≈øider the mi≈øerie of his end, and in how ≈øhort a tyme all his glorie is to be re≈øolued into ≈ømoke, he wilbe con≈øtrayned to lay a ≈øide all pride of mynde, and to cloath him≈øelfe with humilitie and lowlines.
